an4.11:1.1: “Mendicants, suppose a mendicant has a sensual, malicious, or cruel thought while walking.
an4.11:1.2: They tolerate it and don’t give it up, get rid of it, eliminate it, and obliterate it.
an4.11:1.3: Such a mendicant is said to be ‘not keen or prudent, always lazy, and lacking energy’ when walking.
an4.11:2.1: Suppose a mendicant has a sensual, malicious, or cruel thought while standing …
an4.11:4.1: or when lying down while awake.
an4.11:4.2: They tolerate it and don’t give it up, get rid of it, eliminate it, and obliterate it.
an4.11:4.3: Such a mendicant is said to be ‘not keen or prudent, always lazy, and lacking energy’ when lying down while awake.
an4.11:5.1: Suppose a mendicant has a sensual, malicious, or cruel thought while walking.
an4.11:5.2: They don’t tolerate it, but give it up, get rid of it, eliminate it, and obliterate it.
an4.11:5.3: Such a mendicant is said to be ‘keen and prudent, always energetic and determined’ when walking.
